content: There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so the curr_chunk cannot be summarized at this time. The Congress finds that secure access to energy is crucial for national security, especially in the transportation sector heavily reliant on oil. The 1973 OPEC oil embargo led to severe shortages and economic impact in the US. President Carter's "Carter Doctrine" in 1980 emphasized the importance of protecting the Persian Gulf region. The United States considers control of the Persian Gulf region as an assault on its vital interests and will use military force if necessary. Following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990, the US sent troops to expel Iraqi forces, liberate Kuwait, and protect Saudi Arabia. Many oil-producing nations do not share US values, and during conflicts like Afghanistan and the war on terrorism, some did not openly support US campaigns. Many terrorists involved in September 11 came from major OPEC nations. The United States aims to reduce its dependence on oil from OPEC nations to enhance national security. This involves increasing fuel efficiency in the transportation sector to secure access to oil supplies and lessen reliance on countries with conflicting interests. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a Fuel Efficiency Vehicle Credit under SEC. 30B. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a Fuel Efficiency Vehicle Credit under SEC. 30B. This credit allows taxpayers to claim a percentage of the cost of qualified fuel-efficient vehicles placed in service during the taxable year, with a higher percentage for vehicles achieving at least 50 miles per gallon. There is a limitation on the maximum credit amount allowed. The Fuel Efficiency Vehicle Credit under SEC. 30B limits the credit amount to $5,000 for qualified fuel-efficient vehicles with a fuel economy of at least 40 miles per gallon. The vehicles must meet emission standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency. The Fuel Efficiency Vehicle Credit under SEC. 30B limits the credit amount to $5,000 for qualified fuel-efficient vehicles with a fuel economy of at least 40 miles per gallon. The vehicles must meet emission standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency under section 202(i) of the Clean Air Act for that make and model year vehicle. Special rules include basis reduction, recapture, and disqualification for property used outside the United States. Unused credits can be carried forward. The Fuel Efficiency Vehicle Credit under SEC. 30B limits the credit amount to $5,000 for qualified fuel-efficient vehicles with a fuel economy of at least 40 miles per gallon. Unused credits can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. The Fuel-Efficient Vehicle Assembly Credit under SEC. 45G applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. The Fuel-Efficient Vehicle Assembly Credit under SEC. 45G provides a $2,000 credit for each qualified fuel-efficient vehicle manufactured in the US by the taxpayer for their 1st retail sale. The definition of a qualified fuel-efficient vehicle is based on section 30B(c), and the term "1st retail sale" is defined by section 4002. This credit is part of the general business credit under section 38 of the tax code. The amendment adds a new paragraph (16) regarding the fuel-efficient vehicle assembly credit under section 45G(a) to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also includes a conforming amendment to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendment adds a new fuel-efficient vehicle assembly credit under section 45G. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Energy may provide loan guarantees to manufacturers of motor vehicles or engines for conversion to vehicles achieving more than 40 miles per gallon. The total loan guarantees under this section cannot exceed $1,000,000,000, with a maximum guarantee of $100,000,000 per loan. The Secretary of Energy can provide loan guarantees for vehicle manufacturers converting to vehicles achieving over 40 miles per gallon, with a maximum guarantee of $100,000,000 per loan. The interest rates must be reasonable, and recipients must demonstrate the ability to repay the loan. The Secretary will determine eligibility based on application contents and establish terms for loan guarantees. The Secretary may approve modifications to loan guarantees if it benefits the United States and has consent from the applicant and holder. Default procedures for guaranteed loans will be regulated by the Secretary. The Secretary will ensure that loan guarantees include terms for payment in case of default: unpaid interest after 30 days, 90% of unpaid principal after 90 days, and any remaining guaranteed amounts after resolution. No payment is required if there is no default. The Secretary will not make payment if default is remedied before specified periods. The obligation holder cannot receive more than the actual loss. If the Secretary pays a holder under a loan guarantee, they will have rights to the holder's rights with the obligor. The Secretary has the authority to dispose of property obtained under the loan guarantee without being subject to regulatory requirements. They can take legal action against the obligor in case of default, including accepting property as payment. The Secretary has the authority to dispose of property obtained under the loan guarantee without regulatory requirements. In case of default, the Attorney General can take legal action to enforce compliance with the regulations and conditions agreed upon, and prevent any violations. No attachment or execution can be issued against the Secretary or any property under their control without a final judgment. The Secretary may also charge and collect investigation fees. The Secretary has the authority to charge investigation fees for loan guarantee applicants, with a limit of one-half of 1 percent of the principal amount. Appropriations are authorized for the Secretary of Energy for fiscal years 2006 through 2010. Definitions for loan guarantees are provided in this section. The curr_chunk discusses modifications to loan guarantee commitments that change the estimated cost, such as alterations in collection procedures. The curr_chunk amends the Internal Revenue Code by permanently extending the research credit and increasing rates of alternative incremental credit. The amendment increases rates of alternative incremental credit under the Internal Revenue Code and excludes qualified fuel-efficient vehicles from average fuel economy calculations for manufacturers. The amendment to Section 32904(a) of title 49, United States Code, excludes vehicles eligible for a credit under the Internal Revenue Code from a manufacturer's average fuel economy calculation.
